description: [Status: stable] [Name: suspicious-eval-usage] [Message: Use of possibly insecure function; consider using ast.literal_eval] What it does Checks for uses of the builtin eval() function. Why is this bad? The eval() function is insecure as it enables arbitrary code execution. If you need to evaluate an expression from a string, consider using ast.literal_eval() instead, which will raise an exception if the expression is not a valid Python literal. In preview, this rule will also flag references to eval. Example x = eval(input("Enter a number: ")) Use instead: from ast import literal_eval x = literal_eval(input("Enter a number: "))
